Comments_List: Overall an interesting seminar. I learned a lot about ritual and status in South Asian religions, as well as how senses work.

I learned a great deal about the senses and how the senses are connected both internally and externally. I also learned how to contemplate a concept which is inexplicable: Brahman. The course gave me a new appreciation of South Asian cultures, and overall helped change my academic path throughout college.

There should have been many fewer readings, much less powerpoint time, and a better split between undergrad and grad students. A lot of the airtime was taken up with grad students in an imbalanced way.

I love the structure (weekly papers on the readings, then discussion in class) because we had to consistently engage with the material and couldn't skip the readings. That being said, I could have used an introduction to Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism at the beginning of the class so that I understood the context.
Professor Gerety's experience in the field and the fact that students were not only undergraduates but graduate students as well as faculty guests.

This is a great course. If you keep up on the work, it isn't stressful at all and the topics of discussion are interesting. There is a lot of reading/watching/looking at/listening to other media, but it isn't a ridiculous amount.

Yes, definitely. The course was taught very well and in an engaging manner. It was a truly unique classroom experience, as I was able to learn not only from the instructor but other students of various backgrounds. It was a very intellectually and spiritually stimulating environment.
